On the  other hand, the State of Maharashtra has established specified triggers (Triggers of  RWBCIS) for banana crop under Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana in such a way  that no farmer of my constituency will be able to fulfill the said triggers and  therefore will not be able to receive any compensation from insurance company.  The farmers of my constituency are suffering loss in every way. Therefore, I put  forth some demands for the farmers of my constituency - There is no need to  restart Banana Karpa Rog Nirmulan Karyakram which was introduced in the year  2012-13 under the Rashtriya Krishi Vikas Yojana, to take concrete action/measure  by the Union Government to control cucumber mosaic virus which has affected  banana farming in my constituency and to establish new norms (Triggers for  RWBCIS) of insurance under the Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana in  consultation with the Union Government.

Speaker: SHRIMATI RITI PATHAK
Speech: The hon. Prime Minister has taken specific steps to  contain the spread of Corona infection. On his directions, special arrangements  were made to provide food to the workers stranded at various places of the country  and the states were also directed to do so.  Along with it, he pushed our country  forward to make it self-reliant to overcome economic crisis due to Corona.  He  encouraged to make our country self reliant in manufacturing of masks, testing kits  etc. which ends our dependence on the countries like China. I appreciate the steps  taken by hon. Prime Minister.

Speaker: SHRI BHARTRUHARI MAHTAB
Speech: The whole world is fighting a battle against  this deadly global pandemic i.e coronavirus. I want to place a few proposals before  the Government. Let me  begin with gratitude to all our healthcare workers,  Arogya Karmis, Asha Karmis, social workers, and municipal workers. But the  Government must design some social security schemes for those people who  jeopardize their  lives for us. In the past 24 hours, around 93 thousand people have  been affected by coronavirus, but more number of people have recovered. Odisha  has received only Rs 23 crores and 68 lakhs from PM-CARE Fund, but we have  received more funds under SDRF (State Disaster Relief Fund) head. But in a  subsequent correction we were instructed by the Central Government to spend 35%  of SDRF in covid care which we did. I want to request the central government to  enhance the SDRF allocation for Odisha. we have to promote awareness on a big  scale and prevent the spread of the disease. So far, we have received only one  thousand and seventy crores of rupees from the Central Government. In the last 24  hours total number of COVID-19 affected cases is 93,000 and total number so far  is fifty lakhs. Research is going on to find a vaccine for coronavirus.  AIIMS,New  Delhi is carrying on experimentation. I request the Central Government to maintain  Data Register about the migrant workers/labourers as well as COVID-19  status,  details of number of infected patients and name of their states so that they could  get help in future.

Speaker: SHRI DEVAJI PATEL
Speech: New cases of COVID-19 are increasing in India.  But  good thing is that recovery rate of corona positive patients is 90-95 thousand per  day in the country. Quarantine house constructed during British regime at Mount  Abu under Sirohi district is in dilapidated state. It shows the lackdaisical appraoch  of Nagar Palika Parishad towards historical structures. There is no proper  arrangement of water and food for patients admitted to Covid Care Centre in my  parliamentary constituency Jalore-Sirohi.  The number of corona positive patients  has reached to 43 in the district. MBBS Intern doctors performing COVID19 duties  being given Rs. 7,000/- in Rajasthan which is quite less in comparison to other  states.  MBBS Intern Doctors of Rajasthan have made demand to the effect that  'One Nation One Stipend Policy' should be adopted across the country.  The  situation in the country has improved due to the steps taken by the Union  Government in collaboration with the states to fight corona pandemic.  The  Government is taking all necessary steps to deal with the unprecendented challenge  and threat due to corona virus. I thank all our Corona warriors including Doctors,  Nurses, other medical staff, police personnels etc. who are serving the nation.

Speaker: SHRI SHRINIWAS DADASAHEB PATIL
Speech: I am grateful to the hon. Minister  of External Affairs and his team for bringing a large number of people of my  Parliamentary Constituency back safely to the country under Vande Bharat  Mission. The Government of Maharashtra has launched "Majhe Kutumb Majhi  Jababdari" – My Family My Responsibility Campaign.  The Government should  run the said campaign in the entire country to take care of the health of all the  people of the country. The number of Corona patients is increasing in my Lok  Sabha Constituency Satara, Maharashtra.  There is a need of masks and medical  equipments. I would like to request the Health Minister to provide 200 ventilators  in my Lok Sabha Constituency under PM Cares Fund.

Speaker: SHRI DUSHYANT SINGH
Speech: Till now more than 85,000 people have died in the  country due to the COVID-19 pandemic. But India is one of the few countries in  the world with lowest mortality rate. It is due to the timely measures taken by our  hon. Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi, that we have been able to maintain less  than 3% of mortality rate and have succesfully continued to reduce the mortality  rate below 2 per cent levels today.  We must appreciate the efforts made by  doctors, nurses para-medical staff, police forces and bureaucrats.  I bow down to  them for their service to the nation in such difficult times.  In my constituency of  Jhalawar-Baran, along with the Karyakartas of Bharatiya Janata Party, our teams  have distributed food packets, dry ration kits, ayurvedic kaadha, masks, sanitizers  and even footwear to migrant workers irrespective of their cast and religion.  In  Baran district, the Karyakarta of BJP have distributed 3700 ration kits, about more  than 1.2 lakh cooked food packet, 15,000 people were distributed ayurvedic  kaadha. We distributed about 32,000 masks in socio-economically backward  regions of Baran district. In Baran, about 15,000 cooked food packets were  distributed to the migrant workers and 300 pairs of footwear were distributed.  In  Jhalawar district, the BJP Karyakartas have distributed more than 2 lakh cooked  food packets, 27,700 dry ration kits and 270 pairs of footwear to the migrant  workers. I thank the volunteer who all worked hard towards supporting the people  of Jhalawar-Baran.

Speaker: SHRI DUSHYANT SINGH
Speech: I bow down to  them for their service to the nation in such difficult times.  In my constituency of  Jhalawar-Baran, along with the Karyakartas of Bharatiya Janata Party, our teams  have distributed food packets, dry ration kits, ayurvedic kaadha, masks, sanitizers  and even footwear to migrant workers irrespective of their cast and religion.  In  Baran district, the Karyakarta of BJP have distributed 3700 ration kits, about more  than 1.2 lakh cooked food packet, 15,000 people were distributed ayurvedic  kaadha. We distributed about 32,000 masks in socio-economically backward  regions of Baran district. In Baran, about 15,000 cooked food packets were  distributed to the migrant workers and 300 pairs of footwear were distributed.  In  Jhalawar district, the BJP Karyakartas have distributed more than 2 lakh cooked  food packets, 27,700 dry ration kits and 270 pairs of footwear to the migrant  workers. I thank the volunteer who all worked hard towards supporting the people  of Jhalawar-Baran.

Speaker: SHRI GIRISH CHANDRA
Speech: The poor and the backward section are the  worst-hit under the onslaught of Covid-19.  My Parliamentary Constituency  Nagina and the adjoining Bijnor are reeling under huge scarcity of Oxygen.  A few  persons tend to fish out of the troubled water and are indulging themselves in  black-marketing.  Those involved in black-marketing must be dealt with strictly  under the relevant laws.  The hospitals must be equipped with sufficient amount of  Oxygen with beds in the ICU wards.  I would like to place demand before the  Government to lend a serious thought to create more employment opportunities for  the poor and the labourers other than the ones being provided in MNREGA and  utmost efforts should be undertaken to contain the spread of this pandemic keeping  in view ever rising number of Corona patients.

Speaker: SHRI NAMA NAGESWARA RAO
Speech: Some of the areas in the Bill are  either not so clear, or missing.  Policing in India is a State subject which means  there are large variations across the State.  This includes forensic science facilities  as well.  In the results of forensic science aspects are to be explained jointly with  the observations relating to forensic medicine of the regional aspects are also to be  given due consideration.  Every region or State has its own issues and problems.   Specific studies are important and may be promoted even by the institutes of  national importance.  There are other institutions of States and Centre that are also  engaged in similar works.  These institutions, academic research centres,  laboratories and other field units also need to be developed and integrated with  these central and state universities.  A knowledge-pool of the achievements of all  such institutions, regional, central or belonging to States should be created.  To  derive full benefit of the services of these institutions, facilities for early  dissemination of knowledge is needed.  The State of Telangana has opened three  regional Forensic Science Laboratories.  This has made collection of evidence  from the scene of crimes faster and saved evidences from destruction due to time  gap.  Modernization of police force of the State is important to strengthen the  internal security.  The Center should allocate more and more funds under this  scheme and continue the scheme as modernization is an ongoing process.   Modalities may be developed to lay a mechanism for sharing of benefits by  stakeholders as early as possible.

Speaker: DR. AMOL RAMSING KOLHE
Speech: The  Government is praising itself for  higher recovery rate and low mortality rate during this pandemic, I also appreciate  the Government for it. But this Government is also trying to hide the truth behind  these figures because till date about 90,000 countrymen have died. Therefore, the  people of this country are asking this Government as to why this Government was  busy in welcoming the President of US when Corona was taking roots in our  country. When it was incumbent upon this Government to spruce up the healthcare  system, this Government was trying to dislodge the state governments. Today, our  people are facing the consequences of it. Our migrant labourers had to walk bare  foot for hundreds of kilometres. I would like to ask the hon. Minister of Health and  Family Welfare as to whether or not our country has entered the community phase  of this pandemic. If it is so then all the policies of this Government have failed as  about 1 lakh positive cases are being reported per day. We, therefore, need to  recaste our policies. There are no clear directives to the ICMR for donation of  Plasma. As per the WHO, things may deteriorate in November-December yet the  Government of India has stopped supply of ventilators, PPE kits, Testing kits and  N-95 masks to the Government of Maharashtra. This is not fair.

Speaker: DR. KALANIDHI VEERASWAMY
Speech: I thank you for allowing this discussion  which is very pertinent and appropriate.  The first news of COVID-19 as a global  threat started in November, 2019.  Other countries announced lockdown from as  early as 12th March, 2020 and our hon. Prime Minister announced lockdown on  23rd March, 2020.  The sudden announcement of the lockdown threw the country  in utter turmoil.  The medical facilities in the initial days of the lockdown were so  unorganised that people were runing from pillar to post  to get admitted in the  hospitals.  Our leader Thiru. M. K. Stalin with h is call for "Ondrinaivaom Vaa"  which means 'let's unite' initiated the programme to feed almost one crore people  and supply medical supplies for the needy.  The efforts of the medical community  has to be acknowledged. The Government's support for the people has much to be  desired. The so-called financial package was a joke with the people of this country.   I hope, at least, now with lessons learnt from our shortfalls, the Government would  strengthen the National Disaster Management Authority.

Speaker: SHRI RAMESH BIDHURI
Speech: At the outset, I, while paying my condolences  to the family members of those who lost their near and dear ones, express my  tributes to those who lost their lives. We just cannot forget the prompt response of  our hon. Home Minister who despite being diabetic himself had visited LNJP  hospital to make arrangement for 20,000 beds during crisis period. This pandemic  has shocked the whole humanity. I believe that India and the US cannot be  compared on this count. US is three-four times bigger than India and its population  density is 33 people per km while in India it is 567 people per km. The population  of US is 30-32 crore while that of India is 132-133 crore. The WHO had  announced to nominate our hon. Minister of Health and Family Welfare on 22nd  May, as acting chairman of the WHO. The WHO might have felt that only India  under the dynamic stewardship of our hon. Prime Minister could pave the way for  the whole world to control this pandemic. When Corona warriors were being  stoned,  they were being demoralised, nurses were being harassed then our hon.  Prime Minister had called 130 crore countrymen to boost the morale of our Corona  warriors by way of clapping and clanging the plates. One hon. colleague was  stating that there is no authentic data of the deaths of Corona warriors. He perhaps  forgot the announcement of our hon. PM that the family members of the Corona  warriors will be given Rs. 50 lakh in case of death of Corona warrior. Today, we  have about 1059 testing labs, 1055 Covid dedicated hospitals, 1.77 lakhs beds and  23,168 ICU beds in the country. Today, our country manufactures 50,000  ventilators. Our recovery rate is over 78 per cent. Our Government brought back  about 14 lakh people from abroad through Vande Matram Flights and plied about  44 thousand Vande Matram Trains to transport about 80 lakh people to their  homes. Rs. 1000 has been deposited in the Jan Dhan accounts of poor people  through DBT.

Speaker: SHRIMATI SUPRIYA SADANAND SULE
Speech: According to the World Bank  Policy Note on 'Gender Dimensions of COVID-19 Pandemic', such pandemics are  likely to affect women more than men.  Providing protective equipment and  materials and COVID-19 testing to higher populations will be key to prevent their  contagion.  Pregnant women and maternity wards require particular attention.  Targeted measures are needed for a section of girls with no access to ICTs.   Financial incentive programs can help encourage families to send children back to  school.  Cash transfer programs to the most vulnerable groups including women  will be necessary.  India's response to the pandemic has been 'reactionary' instead  of being 'preventive and precautionary'. The Centre failed to ensure sufficient  availability of PPEs to frontline healthcare professionals.  NGOs and State  Governments responded better to the needs of citizens than the Centre.  Until mid- July, 2020, there were only two laboratories in India to test and certify quality of  Body-Coveralls for COVID-19.  It was not until 16th July, 2020 that 9 other testing  facilities were announced.  During the times of a pandemic like COVID-19, inter- state coordination is important to respond effectively to the pandemic.  The Centre  was insensitive to the needs of an average citizen. After the lockdown was  imposed, there was a total absence of any supporting action.

Speaker: SHRI SAPTAGIRI SANKAR ULAKA
Speech: Hon. Chairman, Sir, I thank you for  providing opportunity me the to speak on the COVID-19 pandemic in the country.   The cases are increasing rapidly in tribal-dominated undivided Koraput district.  We have 10 ICU with ventilators in Jeypore and JK Pur Covid hospitals but these  ventilators are mostly non-functional. We don't have Specialists, oxygen supply,  anesthesiologists, etc. to make these ventilators and subsequently hospitals  functional.  I would request the Central Government to set up at least 50 ICU BED  Covid hospital in Koraput.  Another key issue is referrals. Patients have to travel  400-500 km. to Bhubaneswar by road. COVID-19 outbreak and lockdown have  impacted tribals and forest dwellers greatly.  Poor access of tribal and forest  dwellers to PDS is reported from across the States. Provisions under the PDS are  not adequately provided.  Insistence on Aadhar card must be suspended during this  period. The lockdown has affected collection, use and sale of minor forest  produces (MFP). I would suggest to set up COVID Response Cell in the Ministry  of Tribal Affairs and to ensure appropriate guidelines and instructions.

Speaker: SHRIMATI APARUPA PODDAR
Speech: Asian countries like India has currently  facing issue of exponential growth in spread of transmission of COVID-19 in slum  areas of urban cities like Dharavi in Mumbai and the under privileged localities of  metro cities like Delhi. Due to COVID-19 pandemic, migrant workers faced  multiple hardships. There is no medical help from the Central Government side for  the poor. People are jobless. Effective steps should be taken by the Government to  prevent spread of COVID-19. I would urge the Central Government to give special  financial package to Bengal and clear the pending amount for West Bengal. Our  state is facing acute financial crisis.

Speaker: SHRI ANNASAHEB SHANKAR JOLLE
Speech: The global spread of the coronavirus  (COVID-19) followed by lockdowns has affected global economic including India.  I congratulate all the Corona warriors for their great service for the nation. The  Union Government had also announced insurance for Corona Warriors, providing  treatment free of cost. The Union Government has taken immediate step to issue a  clarification to use of CSR funds to tackle the COVID-19 pandemic allowing  companies to take up projects related to promotion of health care, including  preventive healthcare, sanitation and disaster management. The Government has  taken various steps for digital push in healthcare in the form of eSanjeevani and  eSanjeevani/OPD. The Union Government is taking all the steps to protect the  lives of people of the country from COVID-19. We all need to join hands with the  Union Government and our hon. Prime Minister to combat this COVID-19  pandemic.

Speaker: DR. RAJDEEP ROY
Speech: The Government of Assam has adopted an approach of  3Ts-Testing, Tracing and Treatment for managing Covid-19 pandemic in line with  the national testing strategy.  However, the State’s approach is much more  comprehensive and inclusive.  We have taken several measures to bend the curve  of Covid like ensuring sufficient availability of PPE suits to Covid warriors, and  their safety and security as well, imparting training to staff associated in clinical  management of Covid, , setting up of additional Covid Care Centres, increasing  Oxygen production etc.  State has also started a scheme of supplying medicines  and oximeters to asymptomatic Covid patients.  Our Government is taking all steps  to keep the citizens safe and healthy.  Definitely State’s own funds are not enough  to meet expenses on all these activities.

Speaker: SHRI HASNAIN MASOODI
Speech: Covid- 19 entered our country on January 31. The  Government spent the whole month of February on certain other matters in stead   of making proper arrangements against Covid, which include 'Namaste Trump' and  certain other such programmes. Due to lockdown,  approximately one lakh of  labourers belonging to Jammu – Kashmir were stuck in Himachal Pradesh and  Punjab. Most of them got affected with  Covid- 19. Presently, there is a dearth of  oxygen and beds in Jammu. Jammu – Kashmir has been facing lockdown since  August 5, 2019.There is a need to increase Covid related infrastructure there.  4 –  G should be restored for access to digital and online education.

Speaker: SHRI UNMESH BHAIYYASAHEB PATIL
Speech: The Indian Government has also  evacuated its citizens and those of its neighbours from high-risk countries,  including China , Japan, Italy. The scope of Ayushman Bharat should be expanded  so that any COVID-19 related expenses are covered by the Government.  Businesses should ensure that all such employees who we are not on any  permanent contract should be paid their wages. The responsibility of public health  and sanitation should be entrusted to the States. The Union Government should  make a nationwide planning with the State Governments so as to tackle pandemics.

Speaker: SHRI NABA KUMAR SARANIA
Speech: I would request the Central Government to  please advise the State Government to strictly maintain the Covid-19 guidelines in  the BTC area as social distancing norms are being violated there in mass  gatherings and people are not wearing masks also.  I assure all possible support to  the State Government and the Central Government in this regard.

Speaker: SHRI JAYADEV GALLA
Speech: India is currently the second most infected country in  the world after the US. The number of COVID-19 cases is increasing. In terms of  total deaths, India’s number is three in the world after the US and Brazil. The GDP  witnessed a great decline from April to June. While some sectors have prospered  during these pandemic times, other such as construction, travel, retail, restaurant,  weavers and SMEs have suffered the most. The Government of Andhra Pradesh  has refused to support its COVID-19 warriors.

Speaker: SHRI JAGDAMBIKA PAL
Speech: The Central Government has announced several  policy decisions to contain corona virus epidemic.  The Government has  announced a relief package of 1.7 lakh for the poor people and an insurance cover  of Rs.50 lakh for the health workers.  Testing capacity has been increased  manifold. My request is that 90% of oxygen cylinders may be used for Covid  patients and the rest 10% may be used for other chronic diseases.  I appreciate the  allocation of funds to the States and to the poor people to overcome Covid  pandemic.

Speaker: SHRI RITESH PANDEY
Speech: The Bahujan Samaj Party wholeheartedly  supports the Bilateral Netting of Qualified Financial Contracts Bill, 2020. It is a  very progressive Bill. We sincerely hope that in the coming time, it will greatly  help the business and settle the negotiations in the country.

Speaker: SHRIMATI ANUPRIYA PATEL
Speech: I congratulate the Hon. Health Ministers for  making all out efforts to fight with Corona Virus epidemic.  India is doing 10 lakh  tests per day and has done nearly 6.37 crore tests so far.  My point of concern is  that in these pandemic times, India is also moving towards a mental health  emergency. People are fearful, isolated and depressed. I expect the Hon. Health  Minister to wake up to the cause and do something to meet the 87% shortage of  mental health professionals in the country.  Secondly, it has been observed that the  patients who have recovered from Covid-19 are facing problems like scarring of  lungs, cardio vascular complications, sensor disturbances etc. It would be good if  we are prepared to deal with this next situation.  Third point is that there is a need  to pay adequate attention to secure the lives of the people including small children  who collect medical waste from hospitals and also go to landfill sites where covid  medical waste is also dumped. There are certain rules under the CGST which are crossing the CGST laws which  ought to be corrected.  A provision has been made in the Bill that empowers the  Government to constitute a taxpayers charter.  The taxpayers charter mandates that  the taxpayer should be treated with dignity and respect.  Ordinary citizens should  be trusted and if an ordinary citizen submits something then it should be relied  upon.  Earlier, this was not the situation and the system believed that the taxpayer  just cannot be honest.   Earlier, the taxpayer used to think that it would have been  better had he not paid the tax because in that case he would not have faced the  harassment. Speaker: SHRI ADHIR RANJAN CHOWDURY
Speech: I would like to know the need for  creating a parallel fund when PM National Relief Fund already exists.  I would  also like to know whether many China based companies have also donated funds in  PM CARES FUND. The Government should clarify whether our Prime Minister  has any link with these donations.  PM CARES Fund appears to have been created  to conceal the donations of private persons and corporates.  It is not under the  purview of CAG. If there is transparency then why it is out of CAG’s ambit.  If our  UPA Government has fear of anything, we would not have introduced RTI Act.    Another point is that now CSR Fund is eligible for donation to PM CARES Fund,  however, it was a considered decision that CSR should not be used to fund  government schemes.  I would also like to point out that PM CARES Fund has  received exemptions from all provisions of the law meant to regulate foreign  donations.  It is a non-transparent fund.  We are raising various questions because  RTI applications seeking information about donation and donor have been rejected.  The scheme “Vivad Sey Vishwas” has failed to reap fruitful results.

Speaker: SHRI SRIDHAR KOTAGIRI
Speech: The Company (Amendment) Bill is  bringing reforms to minimise penalties for the act of omission without an intent to  cheat. I would recommend a more lenient approach to smaller companies, which  are in  large number in our country,  I support the Companies (Amendment) Bill,  2020. Our State is facing economic crisis due to misdeeds and the reckless fiscal  policy practised by the previous Government. The  previous Government towards  the end of their term, borrowed and spent over Rs. 30,000 crore for electoral gains,  and left a total amount of Rs. 60,000 crore as unpaid bills and spent Rs. 800 crore  to build a temporary structure of Secretariat for 175 State Legislators. This is a  total fiscal indiscipline and it went totally unchecked. Now  our Government spent  just about Rs. 200 crore to bring back to life 1,100 ambulances, the famous 108  and 104. The then Ruling Party made a grand plan to built the so-called Capital  city of Amaravati. They had distributed 4000 acres of land amongst their friends,  family, kith and kin. We are trying to impress upon the Central Government to  kindly hold a CBI inquiry into it. My Government has built village secretariats,  agricultural support centres, health centres in every village and appointed three  lakh volunteers. There are Rs. 15, 000 crore due to Andhra Pradesh under various  heads. I request for its payment as soon as possible.

Speaker: SHRI MALOOK NAGAR
Speech: I welcome the amendments made in the  Company (Amendment) Bill, 2020 to provide relaxation to traders and corporate  sector. Congress party felt that it enacted good legislation and now the Government  considers that it has improved it by bringing these amendments. But I would like to  say that a Ministry should be set up to create coordination among  various  Ministries. The unemployed persons will get employment, country will prosper  and economy will be strengthened if all the Ministries have good coordination  among themselves.

Speaker: SHRI GAURAV GOGOI
Speech: The main objective of the Bill is to  discriminalise  various compoundable offences.  Today, we are witnessing increase  in gradual privatisastion and even airports are also being privatized in the country.   Recently, a Bill pertaining to farmers has been passed wherein  emphasis has been  given on contract farming and which will benefit corporate India.  I would like to  ask the Government about the facilities being provided to corporate India.  Today,  their criminal offences have become civil offences, tax rate has been reduced and  provided labour Court as sought by them.  The land of farmers is being acquired by  various state governments under Land Acquisition Bill.  The criminal offenders are  still out of the country.  The corporate India is resorting to retrenchment of the  employees in the name of COVID-19.  Therefore, I would like the Government to  ensure corporate India creates jobs, creates private investment and practices clean  business.

Speaker: SHRI DILESHWAR KAMAIT
Speech: This Companies Act was introduced in  the year 2013 to strengthen the rules related to the company on time and  amendments can be made in due course as per the requirement. Strong changes  such as accountability, protection of investors and corporate governance can be  easily resolved without a criminal court case. The Government has constituted the  Company Law Committee in the year 2019 to decriminalize the provision of the  Companies Act, 2013  on the basis of its gravity and to provide a better ease of  living for corporators in the country. This committee has made 62  recommendations. The committee also came up with suggestions on how to  overcome criminality in some cases, which would be helpful in large public  interest and which do not include fraud. The committee suggested a change in this  96th provision on the aspect of decriminalization. I support the bill.

Speaker: SHRI ADHIR RANJAN CHOWDHURY
Speech: Through supplementary  demand for grants, I have not found anything to come to the conclusion that some  new services have been contemplated. It is a practice that the amount to be voted  will be incorporated in the Appropriation Bill.  The Budget passed in February,  2020 has estimated an expenditure of Rs. 30,42,234 crore for the year. The  supplementary demand for funds is about Rs. 1.67 lakh crore of which Rs. 1.62  lakh crore is the real revenue expenditure. Most of this amount relates to Covid  relief announcement made earlier. This amount would be 0.23 per cent of GDP.  This contradicts the falls claims of the Prime Minister when he said that India  would spent  10 per cent of its GDP as fiscal stimulus. It was a big lie. The fiscal  stimulus was merely 0.23 per cent of GDP. The Government has sought an  additional amount of Rs. 40,000 crore for MGNREGA. This is the real  contribution. MGNREGA saves all. There has been complete breach of trust by the  Centre as far as sharing of revenue with States is concerned. It is ironical that  States are being made to borrow. This exposes the Government's double speak and  the blatant attempts to expose our federal structure. Where is the Government's  additional spending on infrastructure? The only way to revive the industrial  activity and also to create jobs is by pumping huge amount in infrastructure  spending. The Government is either clueless or does not intend to spend on  infrastructure. So, the expenditure needs to go up to create more jobs. Push the  money in the hands of the people so that consumption picks up. Therefore, we say  to formulate a general grant scheme for poor migrant workers. The Government  talks about data but they have no data about  how many people have been died.  The Government's response to the pandemic affected economy made the situation  worse. We have asked to provide relief on indirect taxes like GST, extend the pay  protection scheme to protect employment and wages; increase spending on  infrastructure projects; pay the arrears of tax devolution and GST to the States so  that they may enhance their capital and welfare expenditure.  If the above measures  had been taken, they would have amounted to a significant fiscal stimulus to the  economy.  Another direct consequences of the closure of MSMEs is that of the 10  to 11 crore MSMEs in the country, it is estimated that all of them were closed in  April, May and June, nearly 30 per cent have shut down permanently and despite  Finance Minister’s instruction, banks are not providing funds to MSMEs.  Again,  according to the official data released by the CSO, it is only agriculture and allied  activities that have recorded positive growth in quarter one.  But demand has not  increased in the village.  All other sectors of the economy have registered huge  negative growth.  So, this Supplementary Demands for Grants has not significance  as economic condition of the country is getting worse.

Speaker: SHRI MANISH TEWARI
Speech: The Bill makes substantive amendments to  eight different Acts, some of which should have to be standalone amendments  because they end up changing the character of the principal Act itself. My second  objection is with regard to the PMCARES Fund.  Since the name of the institution  of the Prime Minister is attached to it, it would have been more appropriate if this  fund were created through legislation.  Finally, the Bill allow force majeure to be  operationalised  retrospectively.

Speaker: SHRI DAYANIDHI MARAN
Speech: We find ourselves in the midst of the worst  financial crisis the nation has witnessed in the last 40 years.  We have been the  worst affected among the large economies.  If a State GST revenue grows slower  than 14 per cent, such a loss of revenue must be taken care of by the Centre by  providing GST compensation grants to the State.   As on date, Rs.12,250.50 crore  is due to Tamil Nadu as compensation for the shortfall in GST collection.  This  money belongs to the State Government and citizens of Tamil Nadu.  At a time  like this, that is during the pandemic, States need even more spending power. All  the States have spent to their maximum capacity to handle the pandemic.  After all,  as per the Constitutional provision, the Centre is accountable  for providing GST  compensation.  If the Centre makes the States borrow loans for this purpose, then  the financial burden would ultimately fall on the States.  Again, this Government  has not taken up economic reforms in the last six years.  Now, the Government’s  data shows that the Indian economy has contracted to a record low of 23.9 per cent  in the quarter ending June’ 2020.  So, I would urge the Government to release a  White Paper on the economic crisis. Further, the Corona virus pandemic and  lockdown have hurt the middleclass the most.  This Government has done very  little to help the middleclass. I would also like to say that in trying to thumps up  the economy, Government has taken away the MPLADS funds for two-and-a-half  years. If the Government is going to like this, let me tell that this Government will  lose faith of the middleclass.

Speaker: DR. KALANIDHI VEERASWAMY
Speech: The decision to cut the MPLADS  for two years is shocking as this is the peoples fund provided for by the  Constitution of India, and depriving the people of their rightful funds is deplorable.  I would urge the Government not only to rescind the decision to deprive the people  of MPLADS, but to enhance the amount from Rs. 5 crore to Rs. 10 crore. The  announcement of the so-called ‘Financial Package’ by the hon. Finance Minister  was a huge disappointment for every citizen of this country.  I would urge upon the  Government to kindly reconsider the decision on MPLADS as there are several  other ways to generate funds.

Speaker: SHRI SAPTAGIRI SANKAR ULAKA
Speech: The Gunupur- Therubali railway  project is in the backburner.  I would request the Ministry of Railways to urgently  take this project up with the State Government and revive the project.  I would  request the Ministry of Railways to expedite the work of Jeypore- Malkangiri and  Jeypore- Nabarangpur railway projects.  I would request the Government to repair  the stretch from Barigumma- Jeypore- Koraput-Sunki and approve four laning of  NH-26, especially the stretch in the undivided Koraput district.  The bypass road at  Jeypore and Koraput on NH-26 and bypass road at Rayagada on NH-326 would  need to be expeditiously approved.  I would request the Ministry of  Communications to kindly set up mobile towers of BSNL  network in all the Gram  Panchayats in Rayagada and Koraput districts where there is no network coverage.   Also, I would like to urge you kindly to ensure 4G connectivity of BSNL in these  areas.  I would urge the Ministry of Education to introduce additional JEE, NEET  Entrance Test Centres at Jeypore and Rayagada to enable the students from  undivided Koraput district to appear in the Entrance Tests without travelling 400- 500 Km.  I would request the Ministry of Education to expedite construction/  approval of Kendriya Vidyalaya at Jeypore.  I would request for a one- time grant  of Rs. 500 crore for infrastructure development of CUO, Odisha.  I would request  the Government to set up Air Ambulance at Jeypore airport strip.  Under Phase III  of the Centrally- sponsored scheme for setting up of medical colleges, I would urge  you to kindly approve a Government Medical College at Rayagada.

Speaker: SHRI ARVIND SAWANT
Speech: While expressing my thoughts on the  Demands for Grants, I would like to welcome the grant of Rs. 190 crores to the  Ministry of AYUSH.  The Air India is in a very poor state of affairs and the  employees working there have become unemployed.  Air India has regularized its  temporary workers working there for the last 10-20 years but these do not include  the workers from Mumbai.  I would request that these workers must also be  regularized.  Data regarding the works carried out under the Pradhan Mantri Mudra  Yojana must also be provided.  Maharashtra has worked excellently during the  Corona Pandemic times and WHO has also appreciated the state for its efforts.  I  request Hon. Minister of Finance to provide income tax rebate under Section 80(G)  of the Income Tax Act for the Maharashtra Chief Minister's Relief Fund (COVID- 19).  The State's due GST amount of Rs. 22,000 crore must also be released on  priority basis.  PMC Bank must be merged with another bank at the earliest.  There  is a need to pay attention towards the functioning of Indian Meteorological  Department.  If the Government fails to protect the public sector banks, then there  will be a major employment crisis.  Today, it is most important that people should  get employment and poor people must get justice.

Speaker: SHRI RAMPRIT MANDAL
Speech: Thank you for giving me an opportunity to  speak on Supplementary Demands for Grants.  The fiscal deficit of the Central  Government has increased due to poor revenue collection because of imposition of   lockdown. Economic activities have been hampered due to lockdown imposed on  account of Corona pandemic.

Speaker: SHRI BHARTRUHARI MAHTAB
Speech: India is, today, confronted with a  dangerous trinity of military, health and economic threats.  Global economy will  experience one of its worst years in history. It is clear that India's economy will  contract significantly. The contracting economy can adversely impact our ability to  feed and educate our children.  According to estimaes by ICRA, the Central fiscal  deficit will touch 7.4 per cent of GDP in fiscal year 2021.  I would like to mention,  with revenue collection hit amid disruptions due to lockdowns, the fiscal deficit is  likely to touch 7 per cent of GDP.  Around Rs. 33,771 crore have been allocated  for cash transfer to women Jan Dhan accounts and in accounts of old people.   Allocation of Rs. 16,000 crore has been made for distribution of foodgrains and  other expenditure and around Rs. 14,000 crore have been allocated for COVID  fight.  Rs. 46,600 crore have been allocated for revenue deficit grants to States.   There is a need to push more money into the economy and that is what this  Government has been doing. That should be the actual medicine to revive our  economy.  Government finances are already stretched and there is a major shortfall  in revenues.  Government should make full use of loan programmes of  international institutions. Tax revenues are going to fall short by about 2.5 per cent  of GDP, but it makes no sense to respond by cutting expenditure to preserve the  fiscal deficit.  The friction between the Centre and the States over GST  compensation is the most important political economy challenge India faces today.  States are entitled to compensation; and the GST Council shall decide the solution.   There are migrant workers who are also urban poor.  The Government is doing a  lot of things for the rural poor. There is a necessity to have something for urban  poor.  Recently, Odisha faced severe flood.  Nineteen districts of Odisha have been  affected.  There is a demand from the Odisha government to provide Rs. 1100  crore for that flood.  I would talk about the MPLAD. Those MPs who have already  utilized five crore of rupees, have been provided five crore of rupees but those who  could not utilize five crore of rupees, have been denied. There has to be parity.

Speaker: SHRI RITESH PANDEY
Speech: The Government blame every policy failure of  the last six years to this act of God but the people of this country should not forget  that the failures of the once vibrant promising Indian economy are not an act of  God.  Before lockdown, unemployment was at its peak of the last 45 years. The  condition of economy gets worsened during the last six years due to  demonetization, poor implementation of GST and temporary policies. Rs. 4374  crore has been allocated for Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana. Rs. 500 is  transferred to Jan-Dhan accounts of 20.6 crore people per month.  Is it adequate to  ensure livelihood of these people?  Five kg of food grains was provided to 2 crore  66 lakh migrant labourers every month for two months. But regarding Atmanirbhar  package for the month of May, the hon. Finance Minister had announced that it  would benefit eight crore people. Apart from all this, i would also like to say that  nothing has been provided for weavers particularly for the weavers of Purvanchal  and Ambedkar Nagar in this Labour and Employment budget.  Today their  condition has been further deteriorated.  Over the last six years, the Central  Government has worked to weaken the financial autonomy of the States and this  crisis has culminated during the pandemic. The GST compensation due to the  States now stands at Rs. 2.35 lakh crore. Migrant workers were charged ticket fares  by railways. In Ambedkar Nagar, two trains had been suspended because of  COVID-19. I hope, the funds to be provided by the House to the Government in  supplementary Grants, will reach the poor so that they can get the benefit of the  said funds. Recently, the Government of UP has proposed that it will be mandatory  to work on contract basis for five years in case of Government jobs which is  betrayal with the youth. Crores of youth of the country particularly of Ambedkar  Nagar and Uttar Pradesh are still waiting for employment opportunities.

Speaker: SHRI NAMA NAGESWARA RAO
Speech: The Finance Minister is seeking  approval for an expenditure of Rs. 2.35 lakh crore, which includes Rs. 1.66 lakh  crore for the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. I would just request the Finance  Minister to give the break up of Rs. 1.66 lakh crore as to how much is being given  to each State, particularly Telangana, to combat COVID-19.  The Finance Minister  is also seeking Rs. 46,600 crore towards the revenue deficit grants to the States as  recommended by the 15th Finance Commission. What is the share of Telangana  and when will the revenue deficit grants be given to the States?  Our hon. Chief  Minister, Shri KCR Garu, has been requesting the Centre to release additional  funds in the form of special package over and above clearing the pending dues to  States to fight this pandemic.  Telangana also agreed for GST when GOI assured in  this very august House, that compensation would be paid to States for five years.  But now the Finance Minister is taking shelter under 'act of God'. It is not  acceptable. After the introduction of the GST, Telangana is losing revenue. The  GOI is saying that it would not compensate the GST revenue loss which is not  acceptable.  There is more than Rs. 9,000 crore of dues to our State, Telangana,  towards GST and IGST.  The States are in the forefront in fighting COVID-19 and  reviving the stalled economic activities.  For all these measures, adequate funds are  needed.  The Centre promised that cess will come down after introduction of GST.  But the reality was totally different.  In Telangana, we provide Rs. 10,000 per acre  every year under Rythu Bandhu scheme for the first time in india. We have  transferred Rs. 39,000 crore directly to the accounts of the farmers last year.  We  are giving 24 hours electricity. Recently, in pandemic situation, we have purchased  64 lakh metric tons of paddy directly from the farmers and transferred its money  directly to their accounts. Similarly we have purchased 9 lakh metric tons of maize  and transferred Rs. 18,000 crore for the same.

Speaker: DR. HEENA VIJAYKUMAR GAVIT
Speech: COVID-19 pandemic has brought  several challenges before the Government.  To overcome these challenges, the  Government of India has taken several steps like distribution of free foodgrains to  poor and BPL card holders and giving money to the women who have opened Jan  Dhan Yojana accounts.  The biggest step of the Government is the announcement  of Atmanirbhar Bharat, it will solve the problems of unemployment, economic  upliftment of budding businesses and provide entrepreneurs an opportunity to give  jobs to more people, especially to youngsters.  In my constituency Nandurbar,  which is a tribal area, and there are many problems like lack of educational  facilities, irrigation potential not being fully utilized, malnutrition, anaemia and  lack of connectivity of  road and internet etc. Eklavya Model Residential Schools  need to be opened in every taluka which has more than 50 per cent tribal  population.  I request the Government to start CIPET college in Nandurbar district.   The irrigation facilities should be provided to these tribal areas.  With regards to  doubling farmers’ income, improving irrigation facilities by doing lift irrigation  schemes from Tapi and Narmada river basins, the per capita of income of the tribal  farmers will increase.  I would like to draw your attention that only one NH work  has started i.e. Visarwadi- Khetia National Highway and in that too, the work  sanctioned is only half of the length of the National Highway.  I request you to  kindly sanction funds for national highways so that the connectivity of my  constituency will increase.

Speaker: SHRI SUNIL KUMAR SINGH
Speech: Through the demands of supplementary  grants, the Hon'ble Finance Minister has provided for an amount of about Rs. 2.35  lakh crore under this Lok Sabha. This demand for grants has been presented before  the House in this crucial period, when India alongwith the whole world is facing  the global challenge of Corona. We have to keep in mind that through this demand  for grants we are going to create a new India. The post-independence governments  of India had no power to diagnose the economics but we have recognized that  voice and started the plan to build a self-reliant India through our policies. While  discussing in Parliament, we talk of discrimination against various states. Had the  governments after independence considered the whole of India from a single point  of view, the whole of India would have developed. In this context, this demand for  grants is needed today. Through Demand for Grants, the Honorable Finance  Minister has adopted an integrated approach to Ethics, Education and Ecology  alongwith Economics. This will fulfill the concept of self-reliant India in times to  come.

Speaker: SHRI GAURAV GOGOI
Speech: At this moment, the only defence against China,  the only pill for COVID-19, and the only solution for employment is the economy.  India has seen the deepest reduction in GDP. In India right now, we have had the  strictest lockdown, the smallest fiscal stimulus, the greatest GDP crash, and the  highest inflation rate. The burden on the poor has increased with the rise in petrol  and diesel prices having crossed Rs.75. The States are increasingly worried about  the rising number of COVID-19 cases and shortage of emergency medical  infrastructure like ICU beds and ventilators. The Ministry of Health in Assam says  that COVID-19 cases are going out of control. Instead of helping the States at the  time of need, the Finance Ministry is shifting additional burden of the revenue  shortfall in GST to the States. Instead of asking the States to borrow, the Central  Government should relax the norms under FRBM and borrow from the global  market. This Bill completely misses the needs of the States, especially my home  State of Assam. People of my State have rejected the overdependence on  privatization. I propose the creation of an Emergency Economic and Financial  Recovery Council, similar to the GST Council, a council of State Finance  Ministers with past Union Finance Ministers as members. We need a bold effort,  through collective effort, through consensus and dialogue. That is the Indian way  to protect the future of our children.

Speaker: SHRI JAYADEV GALLA
Speech: COVID-19 pandemic is a shock that not only  shattered our economy but also affected consumer sentiment in an unprecedented  manner. The negative 24 per cent GDP growth for the first quarter of this fiscal  indicates the recession that India has to pass through this year and in subsequent  years, if the corrective interventions are not made.  We are all facing the same  storm but we are all not in the same boat.  Some businesses – such as travel,  tourism, construction, MSMEs across verticals – have suffered much more while  others – such as technology, telecom, pharma, healthcare and e-commerce – have  prospered.  For the middle class and the rich, the pandemic has been an  inconvenience. But for the poor, including the migrant labour and the daily wage  workers, it has become a matter of life and death.  I request the hon. Finnace  Minister to release the pending bills of Rs. 3200 crore towards Polavaram project.   When we look at classifying the expenditure into critical, essential and desirable,  MPLAD Funds certainly fall under critical and they should not be touched and we  should not be denied of that opportunity.

Speaker: SHRIMATI ANUPRIYA PATEL
Speech: At present, the Government has only  two priorities – firstly management of Covid -19 and secondly to re- strengthen the  economic activity of the country.  I would like to tell that the Government has  taken comprehensive steps for the poor during the corona epidemic.  A provision  of Rs. 40,000 crore has been made for MGNREGA programme under  Supplementary Demands. There has been an exodus of labourers from various  states during the corona crisis due to which all economic activities came to stand  still.  In such a situation, MGNREGA is functioning as the biggest safety net.  The  Government has increased the wages given to MGNREGA workers from Rs 182/-  to Rs 202/- .  My request to the Government is that the wages should further be  increased and alongwith this the number of schemes for employment generation in  every village should be increased for MGNREGA workers.  The payment to  MGNREGA workers should be made on time.  Alongwith this, the working days  under MGNREGA should be increased upto 200 days. Covid-19 Safety Guidelines  should be complied at MGNREGA sites for the safety of the workers.  Under the  Supplementary Demands, Rs 5915 crore will be provided for the purpose of  managing the epidemic and Rs 2475 crore will be provided to ICMR for research  work.  Today, the number of corona patients in the country has exceeded 52 lakhs  and one lakh cases are being reported every day.  The Government infrastructure is  managing somehow in big cities and in small cities and towns health infrastructure  is insufficient, particularly there is a shortage of oxygen beds. As far as research  work is concerned, there is a possibility that vaccine for covid-19 is likely to be  developed by first quarter of the year 2021. Even if the vaccine is developed in the  first quarter, it will take one year to reach the people until then it is necessary to  strengthen these arrangements.  Jan Dhan accounts have been proved as a boon  however there are last mile delivery loopholes in it.  Unoperative accounts also  need to be viewed.   Today, in corona crisis, the situation of our economy is the  biggest challenge for us.

Speaker: DR. MOHAMMAD JAWED
Speech: The Supplementary Demands for Grants  have nothing for the unemployed, the poor and Bihar which is suffering the most.  Hon. Prime Minister is busy  in announcing various schemes for Bihar in view of  ensuing  elections.  BJP is responsible for plight of Bihar as it is  ruling the State  for last 15 years. 4.5 percent doctors died in Bihar due to COVID- 19 whereas the  average at national level is 0.5 percent because Bihar has less number of hospitals  and Medical Colleges. There are only 16 medical colleges and 770 seats in Bihar in  comparison to 532 colleges and 77000 seats throughout India. The Government  has announced to set up 157 medical colleges and only 7 are proposed to be set up  in Bihar.     There are 1,42,162 km long express highways in the country and only 5358  km long national highway is there in Bihar. Bihar produces 65 lakh MT. paddy but  only 13.5 lakh is being procured at Rs. 1,815. Bihar produces 35 lakh MT maize  but the Government has not procured even one quintal maize. The farmers are  compelled to sale it as Rs. 700 or Rs. 800 in comparison of MSP of Rs. 1850.

Speaker: SHRI NIHAL CHAND CHOUHAN
Speech: I would like to submit my statement  in favour of Demands for Supplementary Grants, 2020-21.  A supplementary  demand to the tune of Rs. 2 lakh 38 thousand crores has been made to combat  Corona pandemic i.e. for research work  and to promote start up programme in  health sector.  Rs. 68 crores have been released by the Central Government for   agricultural sector and labourers in Rajasthan.  My suggestion is to bring petrol and  diesel in the ambit of GST.

Speaker: SHRI BHAGWANT MANN
Speech: The Government is maintaining silence on  each and every issue.  GDP is declining.  The Government does not listen to the  public. No employment opportunities have been created for unemployed youths.  The Government is hiding behind COVID pandemic for failure of its every  scheme.  No concrete steps have been taken to prevent COVID pandemic. The  Government should take all possible steps to face the challenges and threats posed  by China on our borders. Banning Apps like PUBG will not help.  We are so  dependent on Chinese imports that we even import material require in religious  rituals from China.

Speaker: SHRI JAGDAMBIKA PAL
Speech: I rise to lay on the Table of the House the  Supplementary Demands for Grants for the year 2020-21. Most of these  expenditure are part of COVID-19 relief and also the difficulties faced by the  people due to COVID-19 pandemic. Our Government has provided subsidy on  LPG to the poor people under Garib Kalyan Yojana during lockdown period. As  part of Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana, Rs. 33,771.48 crore have been  transferred to beneficiaries of both women Jan Dhan Account holders and Old Age  Pension holders. The Central Government plans to spend an additional amount of  Rs. 2.35 lakh crore to meet its commitment towards Atmanirbhar Bharat package  and Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana. The Centre has sought Rs. 40,000 crore  for providing grants for the creation of capital assets under the Mahatma Gandhi  National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme and for the transfer of funds to  National Employment Guarantee Fund. The initiatives taken by our Government to  meet the demands arising due to COVID-19 pandemic and also other important  expenditure in the Supplementary Demands for Grants for the year 2020-21 is very  praiseworthy. I hereby support the bill.

Speaker: SHRI MALOOK NAGAR
Speech: The economy of the country is going through  the worst phase due to COVID pandemic.  The poor people, labourers and the  farmers of the country are suffering a lot due to this.  Government must find some  ways to help these people. The sanctioned strength of members of ITAT Court is  126 but at present there are only 88 members in the said Court. The Government  will get lacs of crores rupees if these vacancies are fulfilled and that fund should be  utilized to announce a separate package for poor people. Losses suffered by the  farmers during the lockdown period should be compensated. Businessmen are  suffering a lot due to disputes relating to TDS and Government is also suffering  loss of lacs of crores rupees due to this.  Employment opportunities should be  created for  crores of unemployed youths.

Speaker: SHRI VIRENDRA SINGH
Speech: Being a farmer and a  parliamentarian, I want  that this House may be united on the question of farmers. This Bill is a major step  towards the prosperity of the farmers and strengthening of the farmer community  and thus making the country self-reliant. I would like to say that this is the first  Government after independence which has worked for the prosperity of the  farmers. Unless the farmer is prosperous, this country will not be prosperous. The  farmers will prosper after the enactment of this Bill and the country will march in  the direction of being a self-reliant nation. The Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samriddhi  Yojana was launched in the year 2014 to enhance the prosperity of farmers under  which farmers are provided six thousand rupees per annum.  Again, the boundaries  of all the States adjoins another State. But the farmers are unable to smoothly  transport their produce to the other region because of the legal hurdles. Similarly,  when the village farmer wants to take his livestock to another state, he is stopped  on the border. Through this law, the Government has made arrangements to move  agricultural products from one place to another which will increase the income of  the farmers.  We announced in the manifesto that we will work for the prosperity  of the farmers and their well-being. That's why we have brought this law. Further,  during the Covid-19 lockdown period, the Government of India has performed  remarkably. During the Corona period, production in other industries stopped but   agricultural production increased and the farmers ' work was not stopped. So, this  law is being enacted to strengthen the rural and agricultural economy. Under the  able leadership of the Hon. Prime Minister, the Government has resolved to make  Sabal Bharat, a self-reliant India. The economic, social, political, and cultural  prosperity of the farmers will make the country prosper and it will also work as the  foundation for a self-reliant India.

Speaker: SHRI KALYAN BANERJEE
Speech: This Bill is thoroughly unconstitutional,  because this House cannot legislate a Bill in respect of agricultural produce under  the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution. By this Bill, the right of the State to  legislate the law in respect of agriculture sector is sought to be interfered with.   The effect of the Bill is that big enterprises and middlemen will force the poor,  illiterate, marginal farmers to enter into an agreement forcefully.   There would be  hoarding, black-marketing and profiteering of the agricultural produces by the big  establishments and middlemen.  The power of the State under the Essential  Commodities Act, 1955 is sought to be taken away.  Moreover, the farmers will be  forced into litigations under  Chapter III of the Bill.  Although it will start from the  conciliation process but ultimately, it will end in the Supreme Court of India.   Would it be possible for the poor farmers to fight litigations if there is a violation  of Clause of contract by the superior bargaining authority up to Supreme Court?    In a country where more than 85 per cent cultivators are marginal and small  farmers, the Bill does not actually seem to cater to the plight and safety of the poor  farmers.

Speaker: SHRI TALARI RANGAIAH
Speech: I support Farmers’ Produce Trade and  Commerce (Promotion and Facilitation) Bill, 2020 because it will enable barrier- free trade of agriculture produce. Earlier, the farmers in India suffered from  various restrictions while marketing their agriculture produce.  Now, this Bill is a  historic step to unleash the highly regulated markets in the country.  Private  investment, remunerative price, electronic trading platform and dispute resolution  mechanism will surely help the farmers. The Kisan Rail has been sanctioned for  my State, Andhra Pradesh, particularly, from my constituency Anantapur to  Adarsh Nagar, Delhi.  I am very grateful to both the Central Government and the  State Government. This agricultural reform will surely bring benefits to the  farmers as well as to the consumers and attract more private and foreign  investment in the field of agriculture

Speaker: SHRI RITESH PANDEY
Speech: The Government has promulgated these two  ordinances in order to revolutionize the agriculture sector.  But the Government  which is known to be pro-farmer has not risen somewhere above its capitalist  ideology.  My first point is about the minimum support price which has also been  raised by several other leaders of opposition parties.  To double the income of  farmers was an electoral promise made by the Government and if we go by this  formula the minimum support price should have been doubled but the small and  marginal farmers who constitute 86 per cent of our total population have been left  to the mercy of the corporates and rich people by promulgating these ordinances.   Moreover, agriculture is a State subject and the Union Government is undermining  the federal structure by legislating upon this subject.  Today it seems that the  government has succumbed to the pressure of World Trade Organization after 25  years.  Hence, it is urgently required to bring suitable amendments to this Bill in  the farmers interest by taking cognizance to the voice being raised against these  ordinances by the farmers of the country.

Speaker: SHRI ARVIND SAWANT
Speech: It is our objective to make farmers prosperous  at any cost as the country will never become prosperous unless and until the  farmers are made prosperous.  I know that there are about 2,477 APMCs, 4,843  sub-markets and 1,000 markets in the country and it has to be seen how the entire  system is connected with all these things.  There should not be any kind of conflict  in it.  We have also said that the efforts would be made to implement the  recommendations made by the Swaminathan Committee.     This Bill is not going to benefit small and poor farmers. There should be formation  of  a farmer's organisation to take care of their genuine concerns. As far as the  agreement is concerned, the terms and conditions must include an agreement over  the quality of seeds. It should also be provided that no agreement would be below  MSP.  The increased use of chemical and fertilizers is likely to affect soil health.  Given that, provisions must be made to check the deterioration of soil as well.

Speaker: SHRI ANUBHAV MOHANTY
Speech: Farmers are often restricted to selling produce  only to APMC-licensed traders. The Committee which grants such licenses is  supposed to comprise elected farmers and traders, but is often dominated by  traders. The Competition Commission of India has observed collusion amongst  traders in APMCs. Poor infrastructure, lack of transportation and storage facilities  etc. affect farmers' earnings against their produce. The farmers with large land  holdings are going to be benefitted and the interests of small farmers are likely to  be hugely compromised. The Bill lacks clarity on the issue of payment to the  unscheduled farmers. The legislative competence of the Central Government is  also likely to be disputed as it may result in reduction of the revenue generated by  the States with the prohibition of the imposition of the fee in non-APMC trade  areas. The dispute resolution mechanism needs to be simplified. I request the hon.  Minister to refer this Bill to the Standing Committee for scrutiny and clarity.

Speaker: SHRI SANTOSH KUMAR
Speech: This Bill is going to provide the farmers with a  market of their choice which would enable them to get remunerative price of their  produce. In a way, the Government is going to actualize the concept of 'one nation- one  agriculture market' through this Bill.  There would be resolution of disputes  through a transparent process. I would like to request the hon. Minister to set up a  Maize Research Centre in my Parliamentary Constituency Purnia. It is necessary to  facilitate maize growers. Alongside a Banana Research Centre and laboratory  should also be set up there to support banana growers.

Speaker: SHRI MANNE SRINIVAS REDDY
Speech: Farmers may be guaranteed MSP for all  agricultural products. The rates may be revised depending on inflation and huge  losses caused by natural calamities. Farmers with small land holdings accounting  for nearly 95 per cent of total farmers should be given full social security. They  should be made aware of the existing laws lest they should be misused by the  traders. Existing facilities available to the farmers must not be diluted. 'Rythu  Bandhu Scheme' of Rs. 10,000 per acre per annum to each farmer for two crops  before sowing the season launched by the Telangana Government has received  applause among the farmers. Therefore, agricultural products must be put online  showing the production of  each item in each area.

Speaker: SHRI SUNIL DATTATRAY TATKARE
Speech: The Government has banned  the export of onions and due to this decision, the farmers have landed in trouble.  Lasalgaon onion market is the largest in the world and the Government is trying to  control the APMC there through the backdoor. Now, the Government is  transferring all the powers to the corporate and capitalists and hence we are  doubtful whether the farmers of this country are going to get the remunerative  prices for their produces or not.

Speaker: SHRI JAGDAMBIKA PAL
Speech: The issue of farmers has always been discussed in  this House.  The farmers should get remunerative price for their produce and they  must be empowered.  All are accountable to the farmers, be it Treasury benches or  the Opposition.  At the time of Independence of the country, the contribution of  agriculture in GDP was 45 per cent and now it has been reduced to 17-18 per cent.   Our Government is going to empower them by providing them remunerative price  for their produce.  I think that after passing of this Bill, farmers of this country will  have independence to sell their produce.  Minimum Support Price will be  continued and mandis will be there.   Now, Farmers of this country can sell their  produce in other states.  Certainly, the chain of middlemen will be abolished. As  per the Reports of the Swaminathan Committee, the farmers should get at least one  and half times more of their production cost.  During the last 70 years, the income  in Government jobs has increased upto 150 times whereas it is only 21 times in  case of farmers. Farmers are dependent on nature even today.  Today 50 per cent   farmers are still agricultural labourers.  The percentage of small and marginal  farmers is 82 per cent.  Only 18 per cent farmers are such that have only two  hectares of land.  There is uncertainty in production and market prices remain  volatile.    Therefore, the interest of people in agriculture is decreasing.  After  passing of this Bill, certainly, the productivity will increase.  Production will be  cost-effective.  There will be monetization of production.  By this, the income of  farmers will increase.  The agreement with whom the farmer will sign, that will be  in the domain of State. The State will make their registration and it will be  electronic registration and therefore the concerned will be liable somewhere.  The  agreement will be signed by mutual understanding.  I would like to congratulate  the Government that after so many years since Independence, today farming  services are being discussed in this House.    During lockdown, our Prime Minister announced the distribution of foodgrains  worth Rs.46000 crore for 80 crore needy people for six months.  Hon. Minister of  Finance announced a package  of Rs.1,65,000 crore for creating storage and value  addition facilities for agricultural produce and primary cooperative societies.  The  Government is going to further increase the number of Farmers’ Production  Organizations.  The Government has also given funds for micro food enterprises,  fisheries, animal husbandry, herbal plants, bee-keeping, crop insurance, soil health  etc.   Further, the Parliament is competent to enact law with regard to the sale of  agricultural produce which comes in the Concurrent List.

Speaker: SHRI RAM MOHAN NAIDU KINJARAPU
Speech: Agriculture is a State subject.    So, the legislative competence has to be looked into if this Bill can be enacted by  the Parliament or not.  The Central Government should ensure that the  administrative machinery set up in the States under the APMC Act is integrated  with the existing system once the provisions of this Bill come into effect. I would  like to request the Central Government to use the power under the Bill to specify  rules and allow unregistered traders also to go ahead with their business and give  them some time to register themselves.  The Government should set up agricultural  tribunals for the purpose of dispute resolution mechanism.  Further, the new law  must find a way to address the risk of mono-culture farming which can lead to loss  of crop diversity.  The Government should ensure that the private players grant the  Minimum Support Price to the farmers and the Government should look into other  concerns of the famers as well.

Speaker: SHRI SUKHBIR SINGH BADAL
Speech: By these three Ordinance replacing  Bills, around 20 lakh farmers are going to be affected, more than 30,000 Arhtias  are going to be affected, more than 3 lakh Mandi labourers are going to be  affected, and more than 15 to 20 lakh Khet Mazdoors are going to be affected.  In  the last fifty years, all Governments in Punjab developed the agricultural  infrastructure.  The entire State exchequer in Punjab was utilized for improvement  of agricultural infrastrucutre.  Our fifty years of hard labour and efforts that have  saved the country will now be ruined. The farmers of Punjab have a lot of  apprehensions.  The need of the hour is to save the agriculture and agriculturists of  Punjab.

Speaker: SHRI LAVU SRI KRISHNA DEVARAYALU
Speech: We welcome this  Farmers' Produce Trade and Commerce (Promotion and Simplification) Bill. The  gains from the condensed supply chain will be passed on to the farmers and the  consumers.  Secondly, the market forces will take effect and help in better  transmission of market prices to the farmer. The increased investment in market  infrastructure, creation of electronic platforms and increased exports will benefit  the farmers. But we want to make sure that the Government needs to ensure that  the monopolistic tendencies are avoided in farm sector marketing. The  Government also needs to ensure that the States are compensated for the loss in  APMC market cess. As regards the Farmers (Empowerment and Protection)  Agreement of Price Assurance and Farm Services Bill, it will achieve the goal by  creating a uniform regulatory regime on contract farming.  The Bill provies for  price to be specified in the contract, but it does not guarantee MSP.  There should  be a balance in food production between local needs and market needs.

Speaker: SHRI DILESHWAR KAMAIT
Speech: I support this Bill on behalf of Janta Dal  (U). This Ordinance has been promulgated with the objective of bringing  uniformity in the legal framework of contractual agriculture across the country.  The ordinance also protects the rights of share croppers as well as the farmers. The  agricultural producers under agricultural contract will be exempted from state  regulations.  These products will be exempted from any mandi duty/tax/cess etc.  The farmers will be happy with the implementation of this Bill. This will reduce  the cost of marketing and improve the income of farmers. The farmers will have  access to the high value agriculture technology and consultancy.  Along with this,  they will get ready market for such crops. The role of middlemen will come to an  end and they will get better price for their crops. This ordinance may provide an  opportunity to agricultural institutions, companies, exporters, processors and  traders to work in a modern way in the fields with farmers.

Speaker: SHRI DUSHYANT SINGH
Speech: I represent Jhalawar-Baran. 'One Nation, One  Market' will be beneficial for selling surplus crops in all areas. Today, the primary  sector has shown a considerable growth. During this pandemic period, people will  get the opportunity to get jobs in the primary sector and investment in this sector  will help the small entrepreneurs. The warehousing, the storage and the logistic  parks will also be of great help. There will be a lot of opportunities for the private  investment at local levels like in cold storage and warehousing. The traders will get  opportunities. The traders from Jhalawar can sell their garlic or can sell their  oranges from Jhalawar not only at the urban mandi but they can sell their produce  in all parts of India. The Standing Committee on Agriculture (2018-19) had  mentioned that the APMC Act needs a change. The hon. Prime Minister and the  hon. Minister have made some changes. The object of the Ordinance is that it gives  the farmer the freedom of choice of trade and commerce. It brings the trader into  the formal economy. It also helps the SPOs. The primary agricultural societies  have also been given the opportunity to trade their produce on electronic platforms.  So, there will be no market cess; and there will be a dispute resolution mechanism.  With this, crop diversification will take place and it will give opportunities for the  farmers to grow their crops and sell the materials in all parts of India. The  industries will get the opportunity to make investments in agriculture and the  produce of agriculture will also get the opportunity to grow. National Agriculture  Marker, e-Nam, will encourage the sale of goods. The government of India has  made tremendous progress in procurement of wheat. In the State of Rajasthan, the  procurement has grown from year to year. I belong to Jhalawar-Baran. The farmers  at my parliamentary constituency can do farming outside their region and it will  develop our region and the 86 percent of small farmers will be benefited.  This will  benefit all our traders.  It will bring a new hope all over the country.  The respected  Prime Minister also talked about minimum support price.  We are getting more  than 58 percent of tur dal.  The hon. Minister has sanctioned fund for the Fasal  Bhima Yojana and it has benefited the people of our region.

Speaker: SHRI SYED IMTIAZ JALEEL
Speech: How many time we heard in 70 years  that after this Bill, the lives of the farmers will get better. But, after that the  condition of the farmers gets worse. Farmers movement is going on in  Maharashtra.  They say that they have produced the onion. You have banned  export. Why the Government has banned the export? If you bring a law against  them, then I want to ask the Government a question that who will bring a law  against the Government?  During the time of Corona, when the price of crude oil  has come down to two-three dollars per barrel, you did not lower the price of petrol  but raised it gradually. Eight-ten years ago, the price of onion reached 50 rupees to  60 rupees. At that time, the price of onion given to the farmer was 12 to 15 rupees  only but the market rate was between 55 to 65 rupees. This means that farmer was  working hard but someone else was taking the benefit. If this law can stop the  suicide of farmers, then the whole House will definitely support this. But I know  that the Government is bringing this law just to take credit.

Speaker: SHRI RAMSHIROMANI VERMA
Speech: Both these Bills will work less  towards the empowerment of farmers, but more in the interest of industrialists. As  the government says that the farmer can sell his produce directly at any market  (mandi) of the nation, then the government should have taken care that the market  tax imposed on the produce of the farmer should be uniform in all the mandis. In  the second ordinance, the government says that in case of a dispute between  farmers and businessmen, only the SDM and District Magistrate of the district will  be competent officers, who can settle the disputes and these disputes will not go to  the courts. This reduces the possibility of farmers getting justice.

Speaker: SHRIMATI NAVNEET RAVI RANA
Speech: Today along with giving birthday  greetings to the Prime Minister, I welcome the Bill allowing the farmers to sell  their produce outside the Agricultural Produce Market Committee. I request that  under the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana in Maharashtra, twelve  thousand rupees should be given annually instead of six thousand rupees being  given to farmers at present. Onion exports have been banned for a few days. If the  price of onion has increased, it will directly benefit the farmers. The ban on onion  exports should be removed. Vidarbha is a drought prone region remains. Where  there is a lot of drought, the farmers will benefit greatly from this Bill. In  Maharashtra, 90 percent fake seeds have been given to farmers through 'mahabeez'.  Immediate action should be taken against the companies and the people involved  in supplying the said seeds. I request that the central government should help the  people in Gondia Bhandara, Chandrapur in Maharashtra badly affected by flood.

Speaker: SHRI PRAJWAL REVANNA
Speech: I express my unhappiness about the Bills  introduced in 2020 with regard to the farming sector.  Government is telling the  farmers that they can sell their farm produce across the country, not only in the  APMC yard.  But this practice has been there since several years and it is not  anything new according to the Farmers’ Produce Trade and Commerce Bill.  I  want to seek clarification whether there is any plan of bringing the medium and  large farmers into the purview of Income Tax Act.  There is a strong rumor that, in  future, the present Government is going to close all the APMC yards across the  country.  In that case, the small and marginal farmers, cannot afford long-distance  transportation of their farm produce.  It will in turn affect the farmers in these  sectors.  I feel that the Government is under pressure from the WTO and  economically developed countries to bring in changes in the policies of the  developing countries. These developed countries will take advantage of these Bills.
